user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_set_thread_name_:
```c
static int
MHD_set_thread_name_ (const MHD_thread_ID_native_ thread_id,
                      const char *thread_name)
{
  if (NULL == thread_name)
    return 0;

#if defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_SETNAME_NP_GNU)
  return ! pthread_setname_np (thread_id, thread_name);
#elif defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_SET_NAME_NP_FREEBSD)
  /* FreeBSD and OpenBSD use different function name and void return type */
  pthread_set_name_np (thread_id, thread_name);
  return ! 0;
#elif defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_SETNAME_NP_NETBSD)
  /* NetBSD use 3 arguments: second argument is string in printf-like format,
   *                         third argument is a single argument for printf();
   * OSF1 use 3 arguments too, but last one always must be zero (NULL).
   * MHD doesn't use '%' in thread names, so both form are used in same way.
   */
  return ! pthread_setname_np (thread_id, thread_name, 0);
#endif /* HAVE_PTHREAD_SETNAME_NP_NETBSD */
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_set_thread_name_:
typedef pthread_t MHD_thread_ID_native_
...
#define HAVE_PTHREAD_SETNAME_NP_GNU 1
...
static MHD_THRD_RTRN_TYPE_ MHD_THRD_CALL_SPEC_
named_thread_starter (void *data)
{
  struct MHD_named_helper_param_ *const param =
    (struct MHD_named_helper_param_ *) data;
  void *arg;
  MHD_THREAD_START_ROUTINE_ thr_func;

  if (NULL == data)
    return (MHD_THRD_RTRN_TYPE_) 0;

  MHD_set_cur_thread_name_ (param->name);

  arg = param->arg;
  thr_func = param->start_routine;
  free (data);

  return thr_func (arg);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The following parts of the code were inspected and do not need further investigation for Rule 8.13: the MHD_set_thread_name_ function parameter thread_name is already const-qualified; calls to pthread_setname_np in the various #ifdef branches accept (or are documented to accept) const char * on the target platforms; the typedef MHD_thread_ID_native_ is not a pointer type; and the thread starter receives a void *data buffer which is later freed (free(data)), so that buffer cannot be made const. The only locations that require investigation are uses of the unnamed helper-parameter structure fields (the cast to the struct pointer and subsequent accesses to param->name, param->arg and param->start_routine and the call via thr_func) because the struct definition is not provided here and those pointer fields might need const qualification (or the cast might be discarding const) — these fragments are therefore reported for further review.
